Award.AwardTitle: SoCS: Collaborative Research: Data Driven, Computational Models for Discovery and Analysis of Framing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies framing, a central concept in political communication that refers to portraying an issue from one perspective with corresponding de-emphasis of competing perspectives. Framing is known to significantly influence public attitudes toward policy issues and policy outcomes. As social media allow greater citizen engagement in political discourse, scientific study of the political world requires reliable analysis of how issues are framed, not only by traditional media and elites but by citizens participating in public discourse. Yet conventional content analysis for frame discovery and classification is complex and labor-intensive. Additionally, existing methods are ill-equipped to capture those many instances when one frame evolves into another frame over time.

This project therefore develops new computational modeling methods, grounded in data-driven computational linguistics, aimed at improving the scientific understanding of how issues are framed by political elites, the media, and the public. This collaboration between political scientists and computer scientists has four goals: (a) developing novel methods for semi-automated frame discovery, whereby computational models guided by political scientists? expert knowledge speed up and augment their analytical process; (b) developing novel algorithms based on natural language processing for automatic frame analysis, producing measurably accurate results comparable with reliable human coders; (c) establishing the validity of these processes on well-understood cases; and (d) applying these methods to several current policy issues, using data across years and across traditional and social media streams. The resulting evolutionary framing data will help unpack the mechanisms of framing and help predict trends in public opinion and policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, part of a collaboration with computer scientist Noah Smith (University of Washington) and political scientists Amber Boydstun (UC Davis) and Justin Gross (UMass Amherst), focused on new approaches to the study of  framing, a central concept in political communication that refers to portraying an issue from one perspective with corresponding de-emphasis of competing perspectives. The framing of communications is known to significantly influence public attitudes toward policy issues and policy outcomes, and, conversely, looking at how people and organizations frame issues provides a window into their underlying attitudes, ideology, and mental state.

This collaborative project as a whole developed new computational modeling methods, grounded in data-driven computational linguistics, aimed at improving the scientific understanding of how issues are framed by political elites, the media, and the public. One key issue for the team's effort was the interplay between issue-specific framing and a more generalized, non-issue-specific notion of frames; careful consideration of this interplay led to the development of the Media Frames Corpus, a hierarchical approach to framing applied to an extensive set of media materials.  Another key issue was the computational question of how to characterize textual evidence for frames and ideology, which was addressed through a set of novel computational models. 

Our research at the University of Maryland focused largely on frame discovery, which is to say automatically identifying frames and framing via bottom-up analysis in patterns of communication. Our primary methodological tool in this work was a class of computational models called "topic models", which operate over collections of documents to automatically uncover patterns or themes among those documents. For example, in looking at a collection of news stories about political issues, a topic model might help capture the agenda-setting role of media by automatically teasing out categories like health care, immigration, terrorism, and so forth, without having been "told" ahead of time what the possible topics for coverage were likely to be. One way to look at framing is that it is similar in kind to agenda-setting, distinguishing among possible topics of discussion, except that frames reflect alternative targets of emphasis within a single topical or agenda-setting domain. For example, within the topic of immigration, one news story might be focusing on an "economic" frame (e.g. discussing the impact of immigration on jobs) while another one focuses on a "fairness" frame (e.g. discussing the deportation of children whose parents entered the country illegally). This perspective on framing naturally gave rise to the development of new modeling methods involving hierarchies of topics, e.g. a model that can distinguish that, within Congressional discussion of taxation, Republican and Democratic legislators differ in their framing of this issue by focusing, respectively, on business impacts versus the social services paid for by taxes. Models of this kind -- and, more generally, the development of methods, data resources, and understanding accomplished in this project by means of a collaborative effort of computer scientists and social scientists -- have set the stage for further unpacking the mechanisms of framing and ultimately helping to understand and predict trends in public opinion and policy.
